sub_topic: Identifying the Eulerian and Hamiltonian paths in a graph.
message_1:
Consider the graph below. Determine whether there exists an Eulerian path, and if yes, provide one. Also, determine whether there exists a Hamiltonian path, and if yes, provide one.

![Graph theory image](https://i.imgur.com/0sUGsra.png) 

Note: An Eulerian path is a path in a graph that visits every edge exactly once. A Hamiltonian path is a path in a graph that visits every vertex exactly once.

Question for the student to solve: Does the graph have an Eulerian path? If so, provide one. Does it have a Hamiltonian path? If so, provide one.
message_2:
To determine if there exists an Eulerian path, we need to check the degrees of the vertices. A graph has an Eulerian path if and only if it has at most two vertices with an odd degree. In this graph, we have the following degrees for each vertex:

A: 3
B: 3
C: 4
D: 3
E: 3

There are four vertices with an odd degree (A, B, D, and E), so there is no Eulerian path in this graph.

Now, let's check for a Hamiltonian path. A Hamiltonian path is a path that visits every vertex exactly once. We can try to find one by trial and error. One possible Hamiltonian path is:

A -> B -> C -> D -> E

This path visits every vertex exactly once, so there is a Hamiltonian path in this graph.
